On Tuesday 17 September 2002 18:08, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> You are the first person I've ever seen ask this question, so you may
> be treading on virgin ground here.

Woops. Cool. :-)

> I don't understand this paragraph:
> > What I dislike is that my tests are in fact splitted into the JUnit
> > test case part and the C dummy library part and I would prefer them
> > to be just JUnit tests.

I'll explain what I want to do, maybe it gives me a new idea or helps 
others helping me.

I have these program parts:

a) The test code as JUnit tests in Java. 

b) The Java interface code to the C library.

c) A C layer to which the JNI functions from b) map. This layer also 
does conversion from C return codes to exceptions and data type 
conversions.

d) The real C library, or for testing, a mock library written in C that 
returns hard coded values.

b) and c) compose the Java interface I want to test.

Now I have test code seperated in tests in a) (Java code) and mock 
behaviour in d) (C code). Right now I abuse an file name argument to 
tell d) what a) expects it to behave like. This tears my test code in 
two: halt Java JUnit test code in a) and halt C mock code in d). I want 
to move the mock code to a) to have both in one place, since they in 
fact belong together.

I got an idea on how to make this work, and if anybody is interested 
I'll report back after I'm done.


Robert
